summary: As much as I pray for pol!jon theory to be true, I don’t think it is. I think it’s just kit’s and emillia’s innablitly to...
body:
As much as I pray for pol!jon theory to be true, I don’t think it is. I think it’s just kit’s and emillia’s innablitly to act/create some chemistry between the characters. I think Dany won’t be a villian, in writer’s eyes everything she’s doing is meant to be seen as iconic scenes of empowering women, and jon is jon : a northen fool. 

I want for GoT to surprise me, I’m still here for pol!jon but …

summary: Yooo Beric is still on Arya’s list of names right?
body:
Yooo Beric is still on Arya’s list of names right?

So is my little murder baby gonna go on a killing rampage?

Will Jon stop her had ask her why she wants to murder this man ?

Will Arya have to explain to Jon that Beric sold the love of her life Gendry to the Red Woman and so he’s going to have a slow and painful death?

Will Gendry have to stop her??

Jon will be so confused I can’t wait.

blog.name: deniblogginstuff
blog.title: dying alone
blog.description: I'm not normal.

tags: i don't care about ANY ship
summary: Cat called Robb out when he put his dick ahead of his responsibilities. Remember, Robb’s dick got them killed. When Sansa asks...
body:
Cat called Robb out when he put his dick ahead of his responsibilities. Remember, Robb’s dick got them killed.

When Sansa asks Jon if he truly kneeled for the North, or because he’s in love, that’s not Sansa being jealous (sorry jonsa shippers). That’s Sansa making sure she can trust Jon’s judgement. Jon didn’t have to kneel. Daenerys agreed to help before he pledged himself. And Jon looks appropriately called out, because he knows what he did. 

Now I don’t think the season 7 writing did a perfect job of convincing us of the depth of feelings between Jon and Daenerys. But for all intents and purposes, the narrative wants us to be believe they are in love. So I’ll go with that . I’m taking it at face value. I don’t think Jon is capable of manipulation. I do believe Jon, much like Robb, fell in love, and made a dangerous decision. Sansa knows this, much like Cat did when it came to Robb. For me that’s all this scene was. 

As much as Jon and Sansa are disagreeing here, they’re very much as Stark as it gets. (Jon is still half Stark)

I don’t think Jon’s decision will get them killed though. Most likely, the Night King is going to get a looot of people killed before that can even be a bleep on the radar again. But it’s just a theme repeating itself. People falling in love starts wars in this universe. Robert’s Rebelion happened because Lyanna wanted the other guy. House Stark almost disappeared completely because Robb broke a marriage promise to get with another woman. Jon ignored the North’s wishes for independence by serving it on a silver platter to the woman he loves. It keeps happening. But whether it will end tragically again, I don’t know.

summary:
Listen, I am alone at a crossroads
(Because just like in 7x03 I want a jon/tyrion moment when they talk about Sansa)
*
Jon...
body:
Listen, I am alone at a crossroads

(Because just like in 7x03 I want a jon/tyrion moment when they talk about Sansa)

*

Jon observes everybody leave, one by one. Daenerys was the first. Then it was Sansa’s turn, followed by the procession of lords and Northmen.

Jaime Lannister’s trial ended with a sense of general dissatisfaction and the only thing he can concentrate on is Arya’s strategic absence, Sansa’s startling intervention in the Kingslayer defense that surprised everyone, including him.

“She will be satisfied. After all she was right.”

Jon recollects his thoughts to find out he’s not alone. Tyrion Lannister is still there, in the same position he held during the recently dissolved hearing.

He would like to ask him who he is talking about, but Bran’s words, the careless description of his fall, of the reason why he was pushed out of a window when he was just a child, still echo in his head, acutely painful. He is full of anger, hatred and resentment and doesn’t know how to vent, against whom. The past must remain in the past, Bran said in his cold, emotionless voice.

“Sansa,” Tyrion says and Jon stares at him sharply, in silence. The other doesn’t lose his cool, doesn’t seem to care for the abruptness change in his demeanour. “She warned me. Even tried to tell me that I had been a fool for trusting Cersei.”

Jon clenches his hand in a tight fist on the table. “Did you talk to her? When?”

“You are very protective.”

“She’s my family,” he says, frowning. “It’s so strange that I worry about her?”

“Not at all,” replies Tyrion with a wry smile. “Except that knowing the lady it seems a useless waste of energy. She is perfectly capable of defending herself. Don’t forget what she faced in these years in that nest of vipers, first of all my beloved sister.”

Again, he feels that distinct, familiar sensation. There is something inside him that’s killing him, that he can barely control. A twinge contracting to make room, huge and white-hot. Maybe it’s the idea he just planted (Sansa, alone and scared, surrounded by enemies and without a single friend) or maybe it’s the tone he used, of outright admiration and sympathy. Without looking at him, he asks, “It was that bad?”

The lack of an immediate reply and his quietness is long enough to force Jon to raise his head. It’s in the look that Tyrion gives him, contrite and pitying, that he has his answer. All his fears take form, enclosed there.

“Shouldn’t you be asking somebody else?”

Anger, or perhaps it is mostly desperation, - the need to know and understand. The something snapped, made his mind begin to rumble, looking for information, evidence - makes his vice hoarse and harsh. “If I’m asking you, it’s because I can’t ask her.” He rubs his face. “When she talks about King’s Landing, she changes.” Drastically. Deeply. Undeniably.

“It doesn’t surprise me,” Tyrion admits. “She must not have pleasant memories of the time spent there.” He considers him with a long look. As if he were deciding if he is worthy of the confidences he is asking him to share. “Did you know she pleaded my nephew to spare your father? Joffrey was a wicked boy, vicious like few others. He told her he would allow Ned Stark to take the black.”

“He didin’t keep his word.”

Tyrion nods and his laughter has a bitter and cynical taste. “No, his magnanimity is renowned. He had him beheaded in front of your sister and the entire court, then forced her to observe his head on a peak.” He turns away. “Don’t underestimate the horror of someone who has been a prisoner, someone who has been disregarded and humiliate. Perhaps we should pay more attention to what that person has to say.”

When he is gone, Jon just sits there staring into space.

Maybe we should.

Listen, I am alone at a crossroads

(Because just like in 7x03 I want a jon/tyrion moment when they talk about Sansa)

Again, he feels that distinct, familiar sensation. There is something inside him that’s killing him, that he can barely control. A twinge contracting to make room, huge and white-hot. Maybe it’s the idea he just planted (Sansa, alone and scared, surrounded by enemies and without a single friend) or maybe it’s the tone he used, of outright admiration and sympathy. Without looking at him, he asks, “It was that bad?”

The lack of an immediate reply and his quietness is long enough to force Jon to raise his head. It’s in the look that Tyrion gives him, contrite and pitying, that he has his answer. All his fears take form, enclosed there.

“Shouldn’t you be asking somebody else?”

Anger, or perhaps it is mostly desperation, - the need to know and understand. The something snapped, made his mind begin to rumble, looking for information, evidence - makes his vice hoarse and harsh. “If I’m asking you, it’s because I can’t ask her.” He rubs his face. “When she talks about King’s Landing, she changes.” Drastically. Deeply. Undeniably.

“It doesn’t surprise me,” Tyrion admits. “She must not have pleasant memories of the time spent there.” He considers him with a long look. As if he were deciding if he is worthy of the confidences he is asking him to share. “Did you know she pleaded my nephew to spare your father? Joffrey was a wicked boy, vicious like few others. He told her he would allow Ned Stark to take the black.”

“He didin’t keep his word.”

Tyrion nods and his laughter has a bitter and cynical taste. “No, his magnanimity is renowned. He had him beheaded in front of your sister and the entire court, then forced her to observe his head on a peak.” He turns away. “Don’t underestimate the horror of someone who has been a prisoner, someone who has been disregarded and humiliate. Perhaps we should pay more attention to what that person has to say.”

When he is gone, Jon just sits there staring into space.

Maybe we should.

tags: I ship Jon Snow with long life and happiness
a song of ice and fire
summary: We Need A Stark And A Targaryen To End This
title: We Need A Stark And A Targaryen To End This
body:
One of the most popular fan theories is that GAME OF THRONES needs a Stark (ice) and a Targaryen (fire) to end everything.

It’s a theory that is used to prop up any Jon Snow ship, but… y’all… Jon is Targaryen-Stark already. He is ice and fire all by himself. He doesn’t need anyone else. Jon Snow is ice and fire and he can stand on his own.
